page.title: 01Nunriding Northumberland
page.content: The names of Nunriding and Newton Underwood are evidence of extensive woodland formerly, he Fort valley is still filled with wide deciduous woods, very attractive at all times and providing cover for birds. There is no village, but a numer of scattered arms. Mining and quarring have long cased. Nunriding Hall is mostly cornland, with grass for riding horses that are bred and trained. Newton Underwood has cattle, sheep,corn Newton Red House has extensive cultivation coupled with grassland improvement. Newton Underwood is a deserted medieval village - ruinous house remains with tower vault attached. Lightwaer is another mixed farm. The old wheelhouse or gingan still stands. The house was probably an inn at one time. The nearest is at Dyke Neuk.
